content.content: Hi to all the members of the Maker community! In order to deepen our partnership with Maker, we have been working closely with the Strategic Finance Core Unit and the Growth Core Unit to understand how Gemini can contribute to strengthening the Maker ecosystem. We came up with the below proposal and look forward to hearing the community’s feedback! For more context and information on the support of Maker by Gemini our original GUSD PSM proposal can be found here: Proposal: GUSD PSM The Gemini team has always been excited about supporting Maker and Dai in our various products.  Custody: MKR has been supported on Gemini since August 2020, and Dai since April 2020. Trading: MKR trading was supported in September 2020, and Dai in May 2020. Earn: MKR is supported in the Gemini Earn product with 1.26% APY, and Dai with one of the highest rates at 5.31% APY to our users. Nifty Gateway: Nifty Gateway users can use their Gemini exchange account balances to make purchases on NG. This means a Gemini exchange user who has Dai in their wallet can use it to pay on Nifty Gateway, where a conversion from to ETH or USD takes place. Credit Card: Customers are able to select Dai and MKR as their reward to earn instant crypto rewards on the Gemini Credit Card.  Our exchange is also ranked as one of the top 50 Dai holders by balance. Gemini is a New York trust company regulated by the New York Department of Financial Services. There are no fees to mint or redeem GUSD 1:1 to USD through Gemini and Gemini covers all gas costs to withdraw on-chain. Gemini dollar (GUSD) USD reserve audits are published monthly by an independent registered accounting firm, BPM LLP, and the Ethereum smart contract was launched in September 2018 and has been audited by Trail of Bits. This information has also been mentioned in our previous Vault collateral application on this forum here, activated shortly after. GUSD-ETH and GUSD-BTC pairs are also available on Gemini.  MakerDAO <> Gemini Marketing Incentive We’d would like to encourage the use of GUSD in the MakerDAO ecosystem and we are excited to announce a marketing incentive:  Starting on 01-Oct-2022, for the next 3 months, Gemini will contribute to MakerDAO a fixed rate of 1.25% (annualized rate, calculated and paid on a monthly basis) for any GUSD present in the PSM, as long as the average monthly balance on the last day of the month is over $100m GUSD  There is a Dune query available that shows the current month-to-date balance for community members to check and do their own calculations:        The payments will be credited once per month in GUSD  As we’d like GUSD usage to increase on-chain, we propose that this marketing incentive only be credited if the average monthly balance of GUSD in the PSM is greater than or equal to $100m for the month Maker will have to onboard and KYC an entity to create an account with Gemini that can be credited, and that can then move the GUSD back to the protocol as instructed by Maker Governance   The GUSD in the PSM will not go into Gemini custody or move from the PSM  We recognize the importance of the PSM in securing Dai redemptions and we believe keeping it on-chain is the best way to fulfill that task   Before the end of December, when we review the results of this experiment, we might renew our commitment at this rate, a different rate altogether or not at all  We hope this proposal is as exciting to the community as it is to us, and we look forward to hearing any comments around this partnership. Useful Links Whitepaper: https://gemini.com/static/dollar/gemini-dollar-whitepaper.pdf 4 Website: Gemini dollar (GUSD) | Gemini Twitter: https://twitter.com/Gemini 1 Source code: GitHub - gemini/dollar: Gemini dollar contract source code 3 GUSD token contract: https://etherscan.io/token/0x056fd409e1d7a124bd7017459dfea2f387b6d5cd 1 Independent accountant’s reports: Gemini dollar (GUSD) | Gemini 2 Trail of bits contract audit: https://gemini.com/static/dollar/gemini-dollar-trailofbits-audit.pdf Onward and upward! -Tyler

So thrilled to see this proposal hit the forums. Thank you to the Gemini team for their engagement and demonstrable track-record of whole-hearted commitment to the space. For the level of liquidity that a GUSD PSM leaves for Dai redemptions, Gemini is offering a very compelling incentive to hold as much of the PSM in GUSD as we can. The GUSD in effect do not leave the PSM at all, at any point, unless Dai holders want to redeem their Dai for them. This proposal is pushing the edge of the pareto optimal frontier for liquidity and yield at the moment. As governance decides on what Dai’s optimal asset allocation should be, we are starting to see the engagement of committed partners who value being closely integrated with MakerDAO and with DeFi as a whole. Governance should evaluate bids for allocation on the merits of the immediacy of the liquidity they offer against the yield provided. GUSD’s partnership offer more than meets the mark for Dai today. Going forward, we should favor PSM vaults with at least a corresponding level of commitment to the MakerDAO ecosystem, and strongly disfavor vaults that do not meet our objectives.  image2310×1148 369 KB

tylerwinklevoss:  Starting on 01-Oct-2022, for the next 3 months, Gemini will contribute to MakerDAO a fixed rate of 1.25% (annualized rate, calculated and paid on a monthly basis) for any GUSD present in the PSM, as long as the average monthly balance on the last day of the month is over $100m GUSD   Great proposal and excited to hear community opinions. This is the way that all PSM pairs should be onboarded going forward. The PSM benefits DAI by maintaining its peg close to $1.00 but it also greatly benefits the collateral (BUSD) by creating stability for them to continue to grow and earn revenue from their collateral, which we should be compensated for (i.e. 1.25% rewards).

It seems to me a great way to incentivize the use of DAI and GUSD, as well as not breaking with the basic principle of decentralization by giving the assets to a third party. I can see that it will be more work on Maker’s part to encourage more strongly the use of this pair. Thanks for your commitment to Maker @tylerwinklevoss     adcv:  Going forward, we should favor PSM vaults with at least a corresponding level of commitment to the MakerDAO ecosystem, and strongly disfavor vaults that do not meet our objectives.   I couldn’t agree with you more, but I think the vision should always be to respect decentralization a little more, as in this case it does.

Why does the world need DAI if it will forever rely on the good will of centralized stablecoin issuers, governments and regulators for its existence? MakerDAO needs to ask itself this question. DAI was not built to be a corporation. It was built to serve a purpose. It is currently not serving that purpose. Adding yet another centralized stablecoin to the PSM would take it even farther away from its stated goal.

ChrisBlec:  Adding yet another centralized stablecoin to the PSM would take it even farther away from its stated goal.   Chris, you might be a bit confused here. First, there are multiple PSMs, not just one. Second, this partnership announcement does not involve adding another centralized stablecoin Peg Stability Module The system already has a GUSD PSM.

No, I’m not confused, despite mis-use of jargon. Maker currently has an inconsequential amount ($30k?) of GUSD in PSM. So small that it is relatively meaningless. This proposal is designed to take it from that tiny amount to over $100m. In essence, adding an existential reliance on GUSD for the first time. This begs the question that I asked above.

ChrisBlec:  adding an existential reliance on GUSD   This suggests you believe this proposal would increase overall centralized stablecoin deposits into PSMs.  Why would it? It doesn’t incentivize anyone in that direction. What it does do is incentivize MakerDAO to shift some centralized stablecoin exposure from USDC to GUSD, to earn income. That would have the effect of diversifying centralized stablecoin risk, which I presume you’d agree is not a step in the wrong direction.

Spidomo:  That would have the effect of diversifying centralized stablecoin risk, which I presume you’d agree is not a step in the wrong direction.   We should be eliminating centralized stablecoin risk. Not pretending to spread it around. They’re all ruled by 1 regulatory body and 1 government.

I hope I understand what you would propose, although in the end they are regulated by the same body, this solution is better in terms of minimizing possible damage, unlike USDC which would be to hand them over to a third party.

MakerDAO is not choosing between giving custody to Coinbase vs. keeping custody and using Gemini. They are 2 separate decisions. If decentralization is the priority, then the correct answer for both decisions is no. MakerDAO needs to eliminate the existential risk posed by the centralized stablecoins in PSMs. Not shuffle it around.

ChrisBlec:  We should be eliminating centralized stablecoin risk. Not pretending to spread it around.   Sounds like you would agree (or at least not dispute) that this proposal:  Doesn’t make the centralized stablecoin risk any worse Brings income to MakerDAO  And your main criticism is that it does not move in the direction of eliminating centralized stablecoin risk. In other words, a strict improvement over the current state of things (just not the one you’re looking for).

Spidomo:   Doesn’t make the centralized stablecoin risk any worse Brings income to MakerDAO    This proposal increases the risk that the DAO will get even more addicted to the comfort created by centralized stablecoin collateral than it is today. The DAO needs to recognize that decentralization is more important than this centralized corporate comfort. It’s a clear “no” from the [minority] decentralization point-of-view.
Just for clarity, would you still vote no and prevent that from happening if you had majority voting power?

If Maker wants to pursue a fully decentralized approach to collateral (eg protocol owned vault, etc) we will need a lot more capital to do this safely. Mechanisms like this proposal can help Maker build up enough surplus to make fully decentralized backing sustainable. Don’t see any reason Maker should be turning away “free” money (not involving any additional credit/custody risk versus current state).
monet-supply:  not involving any additional credit/custody risk versus current state   Risk is technically a little lower too as our centralized stablecoin backing would be more diversified
OK, I think it’s utopically beautiful, but I don’t have a solution for that. How do we do it in the DAO?

Spidomo:   Doesn’t make the centralized stablecoin risk any worse Brings income to MakerDAO    Both are true and equally important is that the income will help us achieve our long-term strategic goal:  Reduces timeframe to remove/reduce exposure (my preferred option) of centralized stablecoins as DAI collateral  If you want DAI to be resilient you should favor of revenue-generating initiatives that will be the capital needed to achieve that.

monet-supply:  Mechanisms like this proposal can help Maker build up enough surplus to make fully decentralized backing sustainable.   This, Maker still need to pay its workers, to get capital in order to pursue future plans. Right now crypto is facing lot of challenges and we need to survive no matter what. I think we all in MakerDAO benefit from deals like this with such huge partners like Gemini (I can see the same with Binance for example), even if you think just in a marketing perspective this is just awesome.
This is very cool! Wondering if there’s any idea of continuing this long term instead of just three months? That would probably be a consideration when it comes to rebalancing our stablecoin assets.

Very interesting proposal @tylerwinklevoss!  Overall, I’m in favour and this is a superior proposal that aligns better with Maker and the End Game plan than nearly everything else to date. Since Paxos and Gemini are the two best regulated stablecoin issuers today due to their deposit taking trust structure (at least from the regulator’s and most lawyers/scholars perspective). Because a deposit taking trust is a regulated financial institution that is closer in structure and regulatory requirements to a bank or credit union, as compared to Circle only having a money transmitter designation, this makes GUSD more akin to an on-chain deposit receipt. The difference in legal structure of the issuer is not to be understated. Deposit receipts entitle holders to a different set of claims in the event of bankruptcy of the financial institution and are also more familiar to regulators and bankruptcy court for the kind of activity that stablecoin issuers undertake. This should reduce regulatory risk to DAI and Maker in comparison to USDC. Additionally, Gemini has one of the better insurance legal structures (not necessarily converage) with their captive set up in Bermuda (major re-insurance market). AFAIK they are the only crypto institution to successfully create a captive to date, and the captive registration and monitoring is regulated by the Bermuda Monetary Authority, which is the same regulator that oversees Circle’s USDC Yield product (but not Circle’s issuance). From a custody perspective, this is also much better structured since the GUSD is in Maker’s existing PSM.  Note: because Gemini is the issuer of GUSD, there is no need for them to custody the GUSD because they hold the backing USD fiat anyway. In effect, this reduces middlemen to Gemini and their banking partners as opposed to the Bank → Circle → Coinbase → Maker flow for the USDC that is proposed in MIP81.  On these merits, it is objectively a better proposal. An evaluation of the financial position of the major counterparties involved in these stablecoin deals may be prudent in having a better apples to apples comparison on bankruptcy/default risk.     BlockEnthusiast:  Why can’t you just send the funds to Maker? This whole proposal is quite good, but requiring Maker to make a legal entity to receive funds feels unnecessary.   Agreed. More on that below.     Spidomo:  This suggests you believe this proposal would increase overall centralized stablecoin deposits into PSMs. Why would it? It doesn’t incentivize anyone in that direction. What it does do is incentivize MakerDAO to shift some centralized stablecoin exposure from USDC to GUSD, to earn income. That would have the effect of diversifying centralized stablecoin risk, which I presume you’d agree is not a step in the wrong direction.   Agreed. There is a big de-risking win if the PSMs are better balanced between GUSD and USDC.     lyt:  Not really a good analogy anyway though because of how simple the “product” is. We are hopeful that with the slight tinkering of a few parameters , we can get this PSM filled (& others would do the work of swapping USDC for USD for GUSD). If this doesn’t work, there are other ways to get the simple job (USDC → USD → GUSD) done.   There are 2 options here:   Onboard an entity to represent Maker as currently proposed and have it swap USDC → USD via Circle and take the USD to Gemini to mint GUSD and put it in the GUSD PSM. No issues with slippage and minimal fees.   Maker creates a revenue sharing incentive structure such that it passes on a portion of the 1.2% marketing incentive rewards for PSM depositors and/or MKR holders. The market will likely naturally rebalance to acquire more GUSD and put it in the PSM. A little more difficult to be confident on this given the rev share might not be worth the effort to open market participants.    Further Questions @tylerwinklevoss it would be great if you could provide more clarity on:   What would happen to GUSD held by Maker in its PSM in the event that Gemini and/or its financial institutions became delinquent. Are the funds that back GUSD isolated and held in trust in FBO accounts based on named beneficiaries or are they pooled? ie. who would be the claimant on the USD backing the GUSD?   Is there any insurance coverage (FDIC or through your captive) on the USD backing GUSD? In your post here it says funds are FDIC insured, so I assume the legal entity representing Maker would qualify for $250k USD coverage. Can you confirm? If so, is the FDIC coverage on all minted GUSD (~$300MM today) or only the GUSD held by Maker? This goes along with #1, as the account structure matters. Something that FTX recently screwed up.      Proposal: GUSD PSM   Gemini dollar (GUSD)  bank reserves are eligible for FDIC insurance up to $250,000 per user while custodied with State Street Bank and Trust.    Is it possible for Gemini to send the marketing incentive directly to the PSM address without needing to onboard a representative company and have any manual intervention? Much like I described in MIP81 and what @BlockEnthusiast mentioned, this would reduce centralization and likely also reduce regulatory, legal and operational risk for both Maker and Gemini because you’d simply be paying or airdropping GUSD to a smart contract on a decentralized network and not explicitly paying any legal entity or individual.  Looking forward to seeing this develop!

@ekryski I’m with the team at Gemini working on GUSD. These are great questions. I’ll take a stab at answering each, thanks for raising them and guiding the conversation.   What would happen to GUSD held by Maker in its PSM in the event that Gemini and/or its financial institutions became delinquent. Are the funds that back GUSD isolated and held in trust in FBO accounts based on named beneficiaries or are they pooled? ie. who would be the claimant on the USD backing the GUSD?   The reserves backing each GUSD are held in omnibus bank accounts at U.S. FDIC-insured banks, one or more money market accounts and/or one or more investment accounts holding U.S. Treasury obligations. Each account is in our name and under our control, separate from our business, operating, and reserve accounts, and established specifically for the benefit of Gemini customers.   Is there any insurance coverage (FDIC or through your captive) on the USD backing GUSD? In your post here it says funds are FDIC insured, so I assume the legal entity representing Maker would qualify for $250k USD coverage. Can you confirm? If so, is the FDIC coverage on all minted GUSD (~$300MM today) or only the GUSD held by Maker? This goes along with #1, as the account structure matters. Something that FTX recently screwed up.   The U.S. dollar cash portion of these GUSD reserves, which may be held at Silvergate Bank, State Street Bank and Trust Company or Signature Bank, may be eligible for FDIC “pass through” insurance for Gemini customers in the event that the bank holding such U.S. dollar cash deposits becomes subject to resolution or similar proceedings by the FDIC. For more information, see the “FDIC Insurance” section of our user agreement   Is it possible for Gemini to send the marketing incentive directly to the PSM address without needing to onboard a representative company and have any manual intervention? Much like I described in MIP81 and what @BlockEnthusiast mentioned, this would reduce centralization and likely also reduce regulatory, legal and operational risk for both Maker and Gemini because you’d simply be paying or airdropping GUSD to a smart contract on a decentralized network and not explicitly paying any legal entity or individual.   This is a great suggestion. Our goal is to establish a due diligence process for the allocation of these funds working with Maker and the PSM. We are open to working with Maker to find the best path towards achieving that diligence and are aligned in finding an approach that improves decentralization while staying compliant.

Dear Maker Community, Some recent questions have emerged following our announcement that we would be pausing withdrawals from the Gemini Earn program. We are disappointed that the Earn SLA will not be met, but wanted to reassure the Maker community that GUSD is unaffected and we will continue our commitment to our partnership with Maker as previously announced.  What is the extent of Gemini’s total exposure to the FTX fallout, or Genesis Lending pausing withdrawals?  Per our blog last week, Gemini has no exposure to FTT tokens or Alameda and no material exposure to FTX. Gemini Earn, which is the only Gemini product integrated with Genesis Lending, has paused withdrawals as a direct result of Genesis’ recent announcement.   Are Gemini user funds affected?  No, Gemini user funds outside of Gemini Earn are unaffected.   Are GUSD reserves affected?  No.   Are GUSD funds segregated from the rest of the business?  Yes. Each GUSD is backed by a U.S. dollar held by Gemini as one of the following types of assets: (1) deposits in U.S. Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC)-insured banks, (2) money market funds, invested only in U.S. Treasury Obligations, or (3) U.S. Treasury Obligations. The accounts holding GUSD reserves are separate from our business, operating, and reserve accounts.   What banks or institutions do you deposit GUSD reserves in?  The U.S. dollar cash portion of these GUSD reserves may be held at Signature Bank, State Street Bank and Trust Company, or Silvergate Bank. The money market and investment accounts used to invest in U.S. Treasuries are established at Goldman Sachs Asset Management and Oppenheimer & Co. Inc.   Do you have plans to introduce a proof of reserves or on chain asset attestation?  We do attestations to validate that our total reserve account balances are sufficient to back the on-chain GUSD balance at least monthly. As a whole, it appears that the Gemini community likes the idea of introducing proof of reserves and we have been thinking about how to provide even more transparency. However, per our blog, Gemini is a full-reserve exchange and custodian. This means that all customer funds held by Gemini are held 1:1 and available for withdrawal at any time. Gemini holds customer fiat currency in accounts that are segregated from our business, operating, and reserve bank accounts established specifically for the benefit of Gemini customers. We do not do anything with customer fiat funds unless explicitly authorized and directed to do so. Gemini also holds customer digital assets in accounts that are segregated from Gemini’s company assets. We do not do anything with customer digital assets unless explicitly authorized and directed to do so. In addition to being a full-reserve platform, Gemini Trust Company, LLC is a fiduciary and qualified custodian under New York Banking Law and is licensed by the New York State Department of Financial Services (NYDFS). NYDFS imposes certain excess capital requirements and compliance standards for all assets held by Gemini. At any given time, Gemini is required to hold capital in excess of customer deposits and must report any material changes in meeting this capital requirement to its regulator.    We are huge supporters of Maker and this community, and look forward to continued partnership and growth of the ecosystem. Marshall Beard Chief Strategy Officer Gemini

Unincorporated associations can sue and be sued. See FRCP 17(b)(3)(A):  a partnership or other unincorporated association with no such capacity under that state’s law may sue or be sued in its common name to enforce a substantive right existing under the United States Constitution or laws.  I think the point of friction is that most users on this forum would reject the assertion that MakerDAO is an unincorporated association.

I believe I referred to MakerDAO as an unincorporated “organization” and the point isn’t about whether someone can sue MakerDAO. The question is whether MakerDAO can have standing to be a claimant in a bankruptcy proceeding. How can MakerDAO participate in any recovery when it is not a legal person and cannot open a bank account to get paid? Off the cuff I would assume all assets of a bankrupt estate in a U.S. proceeding would be converted to U.S. dollars and paid out accordingly to those creditors whose claims have been reviewed and approved by the court. MakerDAO the unincorporated organization likely cannot be represented in court without some specific and novel governance action that a judge would have to accept. So, the thing for everyone to understand as far as bankruptcy goes…if it happens to a counterparty holding MakerDAO assets it is quite possible that none of the assets subject to an automatic stay have a mechanism to come back to the organization. Contracts or agreements the community may have in place among various legal entities to affect RWA deals and agreements with CeFi may be UNENFORCEABLE by MakerDAO/MKR holders in the event a counterparty to any of those agreements files for bankruptcy. It would certainly be in the interest of the debtor estate to argue that is the case. For internal risk management and planning purposes (regardless of what contracts say), if assets are not in a smart contract that Maker governance controls, those assets should be considered a total loss at the time of the relevant party’s bankruptcy filing. This is not legal advice. I am not a restructuring attorney. This is just some common sense informed by 2 plus decades front row seat TradFi legal career including LTCM, ENRON, AMARANTH Amaranth Advisors - Wikipedia, LEHMAN (where I was in-house counsel in 2008). Too much push back here when wisdom and experience tries to speak about things to take seriously and plan for. But really, it is an issue of MakerDAO focusing on legal & compliance risk overall, providing resources and otherwise signaling via an on-chain vote to guide CUs in making these kind of preparations a priority. ~ Kianga

So there’s a lot of back and forth here but @Cryptohippo65 did do a lot of digging and I appreciate the attention and insight we get through these threads.  There’s no way to definitively know exactly what’s going on but at least there’s an understanding of what we suspect and thereby what that suspicion implies in terms of the risk we face. When this deal was announced, gusd’s supply was a bit north of 300 million.  It had been growing slowly and seemed to have an upward trajectory.  As the MKR gusd psm debt ceiling grew, you can see gusd’s supply growing accordingly until it reaches somewhere north of 800 million.  The correlation here is pretty evident.  On November 16, Gemini suspended withdrawals from its Gemini earn program.  Gusd supply drops about 200 million over the next few days leaving MKR’s psm holding a large percentage of what remains.  Obviously there was a huge reputational hit and loss in trust and many gusd holders traded in their gusd for something they trusted more. What bothers me is that MKR hasn’t repriced this deal after the Gemini earn suspension.  The debt ceiling hasn’t been reduced and the rate has not been renegotiated.  Granted, it hasn’t been that long.  But there just wasn’t much discussion (at least publicly).  I won’t argue for completely terminating the partnership but I think based on recent events, the debt ceiling should be significantly reduced and the rate renegotiated.  I truly hope Gemini can recover and rebuild their reputation.  I understand that would be better for everyone.  However, to me, the suspension of Gemini earn means they don’t have a big enough buffer of liquid assets to comfortably cover a large withdrawal event and that makes me extremely uncomfortable with how big the gusd psm is.

Gemini is now providing daily (non-audited) composition of the GUSD reserves.  We also made a GUSD monitoring dashboard. What suspicion that are increasing the risk are we discussing? And why is that not extended to USDC and USDP where any decrease in GUSD would lead. Decreasing the DC would probably not have any meaningful impact in itself.

Because at least there’s demand for those stablecoins outside of that which is created by MKR’s PSM.  If you tell me you want to draw down the USDC PSM’s debt ceiling at any point in time, I feel confident I can go and get a 1 dollar USDC value from others who are willing to hold USDC.  I feel confident because I know there’s 40 billion out there held by many others who trust Circle more than Paxos or Gemini.  You are right USDP is not much better but at least there’s some money out there backing it that doesn’t come from MKR.  At this point with GUSD, you’re basically dependent on going to Gemini directly for your money when you need or want it. At the end of the day, the question is how much you continue to trust Gemini.  But whether you do or not, you do have to acknowledge that 200 million out of the 300 million non MKR sourced backing behind GUSD disappeared after the Nov 16.  That happened because those who were behind that money decided there was a better place to put their money and it was seemingly triggered by this announcement.  To me, that’s the market telling you there is increased risk to this holding.  You are right that if Gemini is true to their word and those GUSD reserves held in treasuries and banks, are kept separate, everything should be fine.  The question is if other areas of Gemini are insolvent, would these reserves be needed to cover other liabilities.  Anyway, even if we decide to help them out and keep the debt ceiling high, shouldn’t we get a little bit more than 1.2% when treasury rates are so high?  Once Coinbase starts giving MKR yield on USDC, this question will become even more relevant.

Commenting in a personal capacity: I believe GUSD does not face any significant insolvency risk, regardless of issues with Gemini Earn caused by collapse of Genesis. Some ppl have insinuated there is a link but there is no evidence to support this, and in fact it has always been made crystal clear in Gemini ToS that Earn program was linked to Genesis and faced risk related to their lending activities. People are understandably shook up after FTX turned out to be a fraud but I don’t think there is any evidence to suggest Gemini has similar operational lapses (vs ample evidence of impropriety from FTX, such as web offshore registrations, wire/bank transfers routing through Alameda, well established conflicts of interest between FTX exchange and Alameda market making service, SBF generally being an extremely sus character, etc). Who filled up GUSD PSM is a non-sequitur. We can safely assume it was someone related to Gemini because they have financial incentives to increase GUSD in circulation due to interest rate spread. But from a risk perspective I don’t think it matters. I think GUSD still provides significant benefits vs routing all of our capital into Monetalis tbill strategies. Gemini has a long history of honoring all requested USD redemptions promptly, whereas Monetalis has essentially no track record at all, having never faced redemption demands so they have never had opportunity to prove they can honor the same. Further, while a majority of GUSD is held currently by Maker’s PSM, there are significant and diverse coinvestors, which offers a high degree of protection versus centralization risk factors. And a final point, GUSD’s effective duration is very short (conceivably it should be possible to redeem 100s of millions of GUSD within days), where Monetalis redemptions could take considerably longer due to operational processes. If DAI faced a significant demand deficit, GUSD could help provide immediate support to the peg, while Monetalis allocations would probably only help after weeks or months. I’d like to see Gemini offer a higher revenue share over time, but I think at present the risk/reward for allocating to GUSD still makes sense given available alternatives.

One point that I think that would be interesting to explore is the level of severity that is being given to the counterparty risk associated with Gemini. To begin with, this counterparty risk would apply to any business that provides funds to MakerDAO, and the points I’m about to make a solely to benefit MakerDAO, and is not a comment on Gemini’s reputation, which I have no reason to doubt. Counterparty Risk Counterparty risk is a legitimate risk in any business transaction. Members have stated that they trust Gemini, and therefore consider this risk low. Members also acknowledge that if Gemini weren’t able to meet their redemption obligations, then MakerDAO would stand to lose $500 million. Given the large sum of money involved, it would be massively beneficial if MakerDAO were able to quantify the level of counterparty risk. I would like to put forward, that MakerDAO is in a strong position to determine this. Actionable solutions Members consider the Gemini’s counterparty risk low, so for discussion sake, let’s say the risk of Gemini being unable to honour GUSD redemptions at 1%. Scenario 1: continue with the current GUSD PSM agreement, but ask for more interest. MakerDAO will receive more profit, but the counterparty risk remains the same. Outcome: A few percentage profit gains, with a 1% counterparty risk of losing 100% of the $500M. (were Gemini not be able to meet their redemptions, due to a blackswan event) Scenario 2: Redeem the 500M GUSD when the GUSD duration ends, and increase the GUSD PSM limit to 1 Billion if all redemptions are met. “Gemini has a long history of honoring all requested USD redemptions promptly”. Past redemptions are a good indication, but do not provide sufficient info to determine the risk of redemptions of such a large scale. Since this has never been tested, the counterparty risk is truly unknown. MakerDAO can actually benefit from this tremendously. Another reason to ask about source of funds would be to alleviate the risk that it’s resulting from credit. For example if the ~$500M USD to mint the GUSD was credit, if the underwriting process is no good and the loan is under water, that credit could potentially be clawed back under certain scenarios (ie. if it was FTX or Alameda, not saying it is). I assume that would just result in an unwinding in reverse order of DAI → GUSD PSM → Gemini → USD, but if the fiat was clawed back (which is what a creditor cares about) and the DAI isn’t burned (for whatever reason) then you end up with DAI being unbacked and since you can’t freeze DAI, that’s a problem. fumoffuXx:  FDIC insures per depositor. in this case Gemini > Silvergate, only Gemini is insured up to 250k unless Gemini is FDIC insured, which is not. So Gemini depositors are NOT covered.   That is not how it works. Gemini’s accounts at FDIC-insured banks are called FBO accounts. This means that Gemini deposits funds For Benefit Of (FBO) its GUSD holders. In the case of a FDIC-insured bank going bankrupt, the FDIC would take over the bankrupt bank’s accounts and request Gemini to provide a list of the clients that make up the deposit of their account at the bankrupt bank in order to determine FDIC eligibility. Thus, Gemini depositors are insured by the FDIC up to a limit of $250,000. Gemini, being a centralized exchange, has completed KYC on all of its GUSD holders. Therefore, providing this data to the FDIC should not be difficult. It becomes more complex when GUSD has been traded and is now held in non-KYC wallets.

All Tbills and funds have a maturity period, to sell it to a secondary person is like passing on the liability of illiquidity. Example: You have a 24mths Tbill, which is not readily sellable on the secondary market. And you are in need of the cash for an urgent matter, the buyer in which you have found is not going to pay you face value of the Tbill. He has no obligation to, and will press the price down as him taking on the Tbill exposes him to liquidity risk. Hence, he will demand a discount.
The Treasury bill market is highly liquid; investors can quickly convert bills to cash. The cash is held in as risk free investments as it gets…

Let’s also not loose sight of the likely fact that MakerDAO at this time does not have a mechanism, strategy or plan for how it as a non-recognized entity would assert and enforce ANY rights outlined in contracts or applicable laws. So, the first port of call is to be aggressively INFORMED about the following on a real time basis:     Eumenes:  actively monitor counterparty risk, particularly large exposures and weaker credits. At this point Maker should assume that their Silvergate exposure is large (existential) and work aggressively to better understand the exposure level and aggressively reduce the risk. Does Maker have a group tasked with monitoring counterparty risk such as this? Seems like a big gap   We should also expect that those involved with deals are: A) not shy about pushing counterparties for all the details to give comfort to the community; B) use the market power of MakerDAO to force disclosures and clarifications; C) treat participants on this Forum with respect and professionalism for raising concerns rather than gaslight them with FUD accusations; and D) encourage all concerns to be expressed, investigated and validate such efforts rather than deflect with retorts to “make a proposal.”

SebVentures:  Writing a MIP is the way. If someone is not happy with holding GUSD, just provide how and where we, as a community, should allocate and let’s discuss on an actionable plan, if any, and not just on some “concerns”. This would be good governance, this is how a open and decentralized protocol should work.   If there is an insolvency issue(and I am not saying there is), then the 2 months a typical MIP would take make it a bad way to address the issue. Someone would need to convince the proper person to invoke urgency and get a vote up asap.

To the point about the MIP process being too slow and unsuitable for emergency situations like this: Something very useful would be for people who care about this to share their opinions on a detailed process for what you are describing. So something like 1) detecting that a bankruptcy is about to happen (how to detect this) 2) triage and determine next steps (what are the options - maybe given different levels of severity, and who is responsible for this and what protections do we have against collusion/corruption/negligence), and 3) how actual execution of the different options available is done, in as much detail as possible to prevent mistakes and corruption risk. These are the kinds of details that we will be spending Q1 working into the first drafts of the scope frameworks - in this case these elements related to emergency risk with collateral counterparties would be relevant for the RWA Collateral Scope Framework

Eumenes:  are you comfortable with Gemini putting sizable deposits into Silvergate Bank, a non-investment grade entity whose stock is down almost 90% year to date?   Don’t feel great knowing GUSD has indirect SI exposure. I personally don’t think FDIC insurance is likely to do much good for Maker in the event Silvergate (or another centralized stablecoin counterparty) defaults. However as a federal reserve member bank SI has access to a bunch of liquidity programs that reduce risk of a bank run situation taking them under. I would feel better if Gemini held a greater share of GUSD reserves in ultra-short treasuries, and then just maintained smallish bank balances to cover creation/redemption. That said, the Silvergate fear could be getting a bit overblown, as I haven’t seen any evidence they lost money in the recent turmoil.     Eumenes:  One a separate note, Maker probably has lower risk by keeping most of its PSM stablecoins in the strongest counterparty which is arguably USDC. Diversification only helps if the counterparty risk of a given stable coin isnt large enough to destroy Maker. At this point a counterparty failure of either Circle or Gemini is existential so Maker has existential risk to BOTH Circle and Gemini which is higher existential risk than to Circle alone…   I don’t completely agree. While having several high exposure counterparties gives more chances for Maker to face an existential hit, the losses to DAI holders from any individual counterparty defaulting could be lower. Also think there is strategic benefit to fostering an ecosystem of centralized stablecoins rather than entrenching a single issuer through exclusive use at Maker. Overall, I think Maker’s GUSD exposure still makes sense. We’ve seen Gemini follow through on sharing revenue, and their capacity to meet redemptions has been proven out over the past month. GUSD also offers immediate liquidity to respond to changes in DAI supply/demand, while other RWAs may take much longer to recall funds if needed. Rather than curtailing GUSD exposure, I’d prefer to put constructive pressure on Gemini to reduce their (possibly unsecured) exposure to crypto focused banks like Silvergate and Signature and shift more of their reserves into treasury bills, govt money funds or other government guaranteed assets.

There is something incredibly fishy about the the GUSD deal and I will continue to provide information so that MakerDAO can continue to make informed decisions.
